Elements Bulk composition (wt%) Surface composition (At%) Ag 3.0 3.8 Cu 0.1 1.4 Epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen over supported Ag–Cu bimetallic catalysts with low Ag loading Xiang Zheng Qing Zhang Yanglong Guo ⁎ Wangcheng Zhan Yun Guo Yunsong Wang Guanzhong Lu ⁎ Key Laboratory for Advanced Materials, Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 21 64252923; fax: +86 21 64252923. Graphical abstract Over Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst with Ag loading of 3.0wt%, the synergistic effect between Ag and Cu is beneficial to produce more active sites where electrophilic oxygen species can be absorbed and inhibit the reactivity of the oxygen species adsorbed on Ag surface, in which the propylene oxide selectivity of 55.1% and the propylene conversion of 3.6% were achieved. Highlights ► Ag–Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst exhibits better catalytic performance. ► Cu can regulate the size of Ag crystallites to restrain their agglomeration. ► Cu can withdraw electrons from nearby Ag and make Ag electropositive. ► Synergistic effect between Ag and Cu is favorable to increase catalytic performance. Supported Ag-based bimetallic catalysts with low Ag loading of 3.0wt%, prepared by the surfactant-protected colloidal method, were investigated for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen and characterized by UV–vis, XRD, TEM, XPS, and H2-TPR. Ag–Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst exhibits better catalytic performance, governed by the molar ratio of Ag/Cu, than other supported Ag-based bimetallic catalysts and monometallic catalysts for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen. The highest propylene oxide selectivity of 55.1% and the propylene conversion of 3.6% were achieved over Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst. XRD and TEM results show that a small quantity of Cu can effectively regulate the size of Ag crystallites to restrain their agglomeration. XPS results indicate that the presence of Cu can withdraw electrons from nearby Ag and thus make Ag electropositive, which is beneficial to produce more active sites where electrophilic oxygen species can be absorbed to increase the propylene oxide selectivity. H2-TPR results show that the reactivity and the amount of the oxygen species adsorbed on Ag surface can be regulated by the synergistic effect between Ag and Cu, which plays an important role in increasing the propylene oxide selectivity and the propylene conversion. Keywords Epoxidation of propylene Propylene oxide Molecular oxygen Supported Ag–Cu bimetallic catalyst Surfactant-protected colloidal method 1 Introduction Propylene oxide (PO) is an important bulk chemical to manufacture polyurethane, unsaturated resins, surfactants and other products. However until now, propylene oxide is still produced by the chlorohydrin process and the Halcon process. In the chlorohydrin process, it produces a large amount of chlorinated by-products which are toxic and can also erode equipments. In the Halcon process, PO is produced together with the equimolar amount of co-product which value depends on its demand in the market [1]. BASF AG and Dow Chemical are ready to jointly commercialize a new innovative hydrogen peroxide to propylene oxide (HPPO) technology. An advantage of the new technology is that co-products are avoided and nothing but PO and water is generated [2]. However, its commercialization has been hindered largely by the supply of H2O2 and the expense of H2O2 [3]. The epoxidation of propylene with H2 and O2 over gold catalysts supported on Ti-containing materials was first reported by Haruta's group in 1998 [4]. The main disadvantages of this catalyst are fast deactivation and low H2 efficiency [5]. The direct epoxidation of ethylene has been widely used in the industrial production of ethylene oxide for many years. The epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen is also the most ideal process for production of PO. However, the technology for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen has not been improved very well until now. The propylene conversion of 0.19% and the PO selectivity of 43% were attained over a NaCl-modified VCe1−x Cu x oxide catalyst [6]. CuO x /SBA-15 or Cu/SiO2 catalyst after K modification exhibited better catalytic performance for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen, in which the propylene conversion of 0.95% and the PO selectivity of 46% were attained over a K-modified CuO x /SBA-15 catalyst [7–11]. Many researchers focus on the epoxidation of propylene over Ag-based catalysts, such as Ag–NaCl, 50%Ag–MoO3, 20%Ag–MoO3/ZrO2, 20%Ag–Y2O3–K2O/α-Al2O3, 60%Ag–CuCl, and 45%Ag/CaCO3 [12–17], but the PO selectivity is low and the Ag loading is very high. Size-selected Ag3 clusters over Al2O3 support could catalyze the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen with only a negligible amount of carbon dioxide and high activity at low temperatures [18]. Bimetallic catalysts, which often show electronic and chemical properties that are distinctly different from those of the parent metals, offer the opportunity to obtain novel catalysts with enhanced selectivity, activity and stability [19]. Bimetallic catalysts are widely utilized in many catalysis processes [20]. For the epoxidation of ethylene, compared with pure silver catalyst, the selectivity of ethylene oxide increased almost 50% over Ag-based bimetallic catalysts [21]. In this paper, supported Ag-based bimetallic catalysts with low Ag loading, prepared by the surfactant-protected colloidal method, were investigated for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen, in which effects of the catalyst composition, the reaction temperature, the calcination temperature, and the synergistic effect between Ag and Cu were studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The Ag–Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst with Ag loading of 3.0wt% was prepared as follows: AgNO3 and Cu(NO3)2 were added into an ethanol solution of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP, M w =40000) to form a clear yellow solution. Then, NaBH4 solution was added dropwise, and a dark-red solution was formed. The reaction was allowed to continue for 0.5h. BaCO3 support was suspended in the Ag–Cu precursor solution, the slurry was allowed to stir for 4h at room temperature, after which the solid was removed by centrifugation, re-suspended in deionized water, separated by centrifugation until no B element was detected and dried under vacuum at room temperature. Finally, the samples were calcined at 450°C for 4h in the nitrogen atmosphere. Other supported Ag-based bimetallic catalysts with Ag loading of 3.0wt% were prepared by the above-mentioned methods. 2.2 Epoxidation of propylene The epoxidation of propylene was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor under the reaction conditions of 0.6g catalyst, 200°C, 0.1MPa and GHSV of 2000h−1. The feed gas consisted of 20% propylene, 10% O2 and balance N2. The total oxidation of PO was carried out under the same reaction conditions as the epoxidation of propylene except for the feed gas of 3000ppm PO, 10% O2 and balance N2. Reaction products were analyzed by two on-line gas chromatographs equipped with a two packed columns (G.D.X-401 and Porapak Q) with FID and TCD detectors. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts UV–vis spectra were recorded on a Gold S53 UV–vis spectrophotometer in the range of 200–1000nm, and ethanol was used as a reference. XRD patterns were performed on a Bruker AXS D8 Focus diffractometer operated at 40kV, 40mA (CuKα radiation, λ =0.15406nm). TEM images were recorded on a JEM-2100F transmission electron microscope. The sample was ultrasonically suspended in the ethanol solvent, and one drop of this slurry was deposited on a copper grid. The liquid phase was evaporated before the grid was loaded into the microscope. XPS spectra were recorded on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with a monochromatized AlKα X-ray source (1486.6eV), and a passing energy of 20eV. C1s (binding energy 284.6eV) of adventitious carbon was used as the reference. Elemental analysis was done by inductively coupled-plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) using a TJA IRIS ADVANTAG 1000 instrument. H2-TPR experiments were carried out in a conventional flow system equipment with a TCD detector. 300mg sample was loaded into the quartz tube reactor and then was heated programmed from 30 to 450°C at the rate of 5°Cmin−1 in the atmosphere of 5% H2/N2 of 40mLmin−1. The catalysts were pre-treated at 200°C for 1h in the oxygen atmosphere. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of various bimetallic catalysts Table 1 shows the catalytic performance of various bimetallic catalysts supported on BaCO3 for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen. The relatively high propylene conversions (>5%) could be obtained over Ag–Fe, Ag–Co, Ag–Ni, Ag–Mn bimetallic catalysts, but the PO selectivity was lower (<5%). Over Ag–Mo, Ag–V, Ag–Zn bimetallic catalysts, both the propylene conversion and the PO selectivity were lower (<5%). It is interesting that Ag–Cu bimetallic catalyst showed the highest PO selectivity of 55.1%. However, over supported Ag catalyst or Cu catalyst, both the propylene conversion and the PO selectivity were low. 3.2 Effect of the molar ratio of Ag/Cu Table 2 shows effect of the molar ratio of Ag/Cu on the catalytic performance of Ag–Cu/BaCO3 catalyst for epoxidation of propylene. With an increase in the molar ratio of Ag/Cu, the propylene conversion decreased gradually, however, the PO selectivity increased sharply to a maximum of 55.1% at the molar ratio of Ag/Cu of 95:5 and then decreased significantly. Previous study shows that PO can be easily further oxidized to CO2 and H2O [22]. If most of PO is further oxidized to CO2 and H2O, the PO selectivity will not be high for the epoxidation of propylene. Fig. 1 shows the catalytic activity of Ag–Cu/BaCO3 catalysts for the total oxidation of PO. As shown in Fig. 1, Ag80–Cu20/BaCO3 catalyst exhibited highest catalytic activity for the total oxidation of PO, in which 56% PO was oxidized to CO2 and H2O at 200°C. However, only 7% PO was oxidized to CO2 and H2O over Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst at 200°C. As shown in Table 2 and Fig. 1, over Ag–Cu/BaCO3 catalysts, the order of the effect of the molar ratio of Ag/Cu on the PO selectivity for the epoxidation of propylene was completely opposite to that of the effect of the molar ratio of Ag/Cu on the catalytic activity for the total oxidation of PO, and the PO selectivity was higher for the epoxidation of propylene when the catalytic activity was lower for the total oxidation of PO. 3.3 Effect of the reaction temperature Fig. 2 shows effect of the reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst for epoxidation of propylene. With an increase in the reaction temperature, the propylene conversion increased significantly, however the PO selectivity decreased dramatically. The lower PO selectivity at higher temperatures is due to the total oxidation of propylene oxide and propylene. 3.4 Effect of the calcination temperature Poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) was used extensively as a macroligand for stabilizing metal nanocrystals [23]. In some instances, the interaction between the polymer functional groups and the surface metal atoms influenced the activity and the selectivity of catalysts [24–26]. Table 3 shows effect of the calcination temperature on the catalytic performance of Ag–Cu/BaCO3 catalyst. As shown in Table 3, the calcination temperature had a strong effect on the PO selectivity and the propylene conversion. When the calcination temperature increased from 250°C to 450°C, both the PO selectivity and the propylene conversion increased dramatically due to the complete decomposition of PVP in the nitrogen atmosphere at higher temperature. However with a further increase in the calcination temperature above 500°C, the catalytic performance decreased due to the sintering of Ag particles at higher temperatures. The highest PO selectivity of 55.1% and the propylene conversion of 3.6% were achieved over Ag–Cu/BaCO3 catalyst calcined at 450°C. 3.5 Stability of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst Fig. 3 shows the stability of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst for epoxidation of propylene. With an increase in time on stream, the propylene conversion decreased significantly from 3.6% at the first hour to 1.5% at the sixth hour, however the PO selectivity kept nearly the same value. Fig. 4 shows the propylene conversion of the fresh, deactivated and regenerated Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalysts. The PO selectivity of the fresh, deactivated and regenerated Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalysts kept nearly the same value of 55%. As shown in Fig. 4, the catalytic performance of the deactivated Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst can be resumed after regeneration at 450°C for 4h in the nitrogen atmosphere, which indicates that coking is the reason for catalyst deactivation. 3.6 Characterization of catalysts 3.6.1 UV–vis Fig. 5 shows UV–vis spectra of the colloidal Ag–Cu bimetallic nanoparticles with different molar ratios of Ag/Cu. Only one absorption peak was observed for the colloidal Ag–Cu bimetallic nanoparticles and the absorption peak shifted to longer wavelength with decreasing the molar ratio of Ag/Cu, which indicates that the nanoparticles are bimetallic and not a mixture of Ag nanoparticles and Cu nanoparticles. 3.6.2 XRD Fig. 6 shows XRD patterns of Ag–Cu/BaCO3 catalysts. All catalysts were calcined in the nitrogen atmosphere at 450°C for 4h. As shown in Fig. 6, the diffraction peaks of Cu could not be observed due to its low loading. Over 20%Ag–0.1%Y2O3–0.1%K2O/α-Al2O3 catalyst, there were four characteristic diffraction peaks of Ag at 2θ =38.1°, 44.3°, 64.4° and 77.4°, corresponding to the crystal faces of Ag (111), (200), (220) and (311) [14]. However, only the characteristic diffraction peak of Ag (111) could be observed in Fig. 6 because of low Ag loading of 3.0wt%. The size of Ag crystallites was determined by Scherrer's equation with the full peak width at half maximum height of the diffraction peak of Ag (111). The size of Ag crystallites of Ag/BaCO3 catalyst was about 33nm. The size of Ag crystallites of Ag/BaCO3 catalyst was larger than that of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst, and the presence of Cu made the size of Ag crystallites decrease from 33nm to 27nm, which indicates that a small quantity of Cu can effectively regulate the size of Ag crystallites to restrain agglomeration. 3.6.3 TEM Fig. 7 shows TEM images of Ag/BaCO3 and Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalysts. The size of Ag nanoparticles of Ag/BaCO3 catalyst was larger than that of Ag–Cu nanoparticles of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst. The result indicates that the presence of Cu decreases the size of Ag–Cu nanoparticles and therefore effectively regulates the size of Ag–Cu nanoparticles to restrain agglomeration, which is also confirmed by XRD. 3.6.4 XPS Fig. 8 shows Ag3d XPS spectra of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 and Ag/BaCO3 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8, the binding energies of Ag3d5/2 and Ag3d3/2 of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst (a) were 367.9 and 373.9eV, respectively. The binding energies of Ag3d5/2 and Ag3d3/2 of Ag/BaCO3 catalyst (b) were 367.3 and 373.3eV, respectively. Ag3d binding energies of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst were higher than those of Ag/BaCO3 catalyst. Fig. 9 shows Cu2p XPS spectra of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 (a) and Cu/BaCO3 (b) catalysts. As shown in Fig. 9, the binding energies of Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2 of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst (a) were 931.7 and 951.5eV, respectively. The binding energies of Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2 of Cu/BaCO3 catalyst (b) were 932.8 and 952.6eV, respectively. Cu2p binding energies of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst were lower than those of Cu/BaCO3 catalyst. The interaction between Cu and Ag made Ag3d binding energies increase and Cu2p binding energies decrease obviously. The presence of Cu can withdraw electrons from nearby Ag and thus make Ag electropositive, which is beneficial to produce more active sites where electrophilic oxygen species can be absorbed to increase the PO selectivity. The PO selectivity of 55.1% was achieved over Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst. However, the PO selectivities of 10.2% and 5.5% were achieved over Ag/BaCO3 and Cu/BaCO3 catalysts, respectively. The similar results were reported by Yang [27], that is to say, adding Re into Ag catalyst led to Ag electron-deficient, and hence the selectivity of ethylene oxide was increased greatly. Table 4 shows the bulk composition and surface composition of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst. The bulk composition and surface composition of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst was determined by ICP-AES and XPS, respectively. The surface composition of the molar ratio of Ag/Cu of 3.8:1.4 of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst was different from the bulk composition of the molar ratio of Ag/Cu of 95:5 of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst, which indicates that the surface of Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst was enriched with Cu. 3.6.5 H2-TPR Fig. 10 shows H2-TPR profiles of Ag/BaCO3, Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 and Cu/BaCO3 catalysts. The catalyst was pre-treated at 200°C for 1h in the oxygen atmosphere before H2-TPR experiment. Over Ag/BaCO3 catalyst and Cu/BaCO3 catalyst, there was only a reduction peak of hydrogen at 155°C and 225°C, respectively. Over Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst, there were two reduction peaks of hydrogen at 175°C and 205°C, in which the former peak was ascribed to reduction of the oxygen species adsorbed on Ag surface, and the latter peak was ascribed to reduction of the oxygen species adsorbed on Cu surface. The interaction between Cu and Ag made the former reduction peak shift to higher temperature and the latter reduction peak shift to lower temperature. As shown in Table 1 and Fig. 10, the oxygen species adsorbed on Ag surface show better catalytic performance for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen than the oxygen species adsorbed on Cu surface. Over Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 catalyst, the former reduction peak shifts to higher temperature, which inhibits the further total oxidation of PO and hence increases the PO selectivity. The peak area of the former reduction peak is enlarged, which increases the propylene conversion. Therefore the interaction between Cu and Ag regulates the reactivity and the amount of the oxygen species adsorbed on Ag surfaces, that is to say, the synergistic effect between Cu and Ag increases the catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions Ag–Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst with low Ag loading of 3.0wt%, prepared by the surfactant-protected colloidal method, exhibits better catalytic performance than other supported Ag-based bimetallic catalysts and monometallic catalysts for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen. The highest PO selectivity of 55.1% and the propylene conversion of 3.6% were achieved over Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst. The synergistic effect between Ag and Cu is beneficial to produce more active sites where electrophilic oxygen species can be absorbed and inhibit the reactivity of the oxygen species adsorbed on Ag surface, which plays an important role in increasing the PO selectivity. Acknowledgments This project was supported by National Basic Research Program of China (2010CB732300) and Commission of Science and Technology of Shanghai Municipality (09JC1404000), Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University (NCET-09-0343), Shu Guang Project of Shanghai Municipal Education Commission and Shanghai Education Development Foundation (10SG30). coredata.dc:description: Supported Ag-based bimetallic catalysts with low Ag loading of 3.0wt%, prepared by the surfactant-protected colloidal method, were investigated for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen and characterized by UV–vis, XRD, TEM, XPS, and H2-TPR. Ag–Cu/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst exhibits better catalytic performance, governed by the molar ratio of Ag/Cu, than other supported Ag-based bimetallic catalysts and monometallic catalysts for the epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen. The highest propylene oxide selectivity of 55.1% and the propylene conversion of 3.6% were achieved over Ag95–Cu5/BaCO3 bimetallic catalyst. XRD and TEM results show that a small quantity of Cu can effectively regulate the size of Ag crystallites to restrain their agglomeration. XPS results indicate that the presence of Cu can withdraw electrons from nearby Ag and thus make Ag electropositive, which is beneficial to produce more active sites where electrophilic oxygen species can be absorbed to increase the propylene oxide selectivity. H2-TPR results show that the reactivity and the amount of the oxygen species adsorbed on Ag surface can be regulated by the synergistic effect between Ag and Cu, which plays an important role in increasing the propylene oxide selectivity and the propylene conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Epoxidation of propylene by molecular oxygen over supported Ag–Cu bimetallic catalysts with low Ag loading
